pros:
Adecco is a market leader and a global corporation.  As such we have excellent bargaining power and tend to get top clients. When the market is unstable (such as now) we tend to still do quite well.  Other employees in Boutique Agencies might get paid more but their future is more unstable.

Progression opportunities are also excellent.  The Adecco group is made up of several large "Sister" companies - if there are no opportunities in your area, you can easily transfer your skills to another company within the group.

The Christmas parties are also brilliant!!
cons:
As with lots of larger companies communication from Senior Management to Middle management is very poor.  Our working hours were decreased recently (which is great!) but we were all told via an email to the whole company - My boss would have liked to have been told before, so that he could plan our business better and prepare us for the news.

Middle managers are often people that have proved themselves to be good sales people but this doesn't mean that they are good managers.  They are often rewarded for doing a good sales job by being promoted and being given their own team, without proving first that they know how to manage the team.

review_title: Great Environment in the Perm Team
pros:
(All the statements below can only be applied to the perm division)

*All bosses within the perm team are friendly
*They don't really give pressure on consultants
*If you are looking for a place to start your recruitment career, it is the right place
*Casual Friday, 2-hour early off per month, Incentive trip twice a year
*In some particular desks, they have lots of clients you can fill such as Customer Service and Retail
*Promotion path is clear and stated black and white
*Definitely achievable targets
cons:
*Bad location (Fortress Hill)
*Sometimes, the atmosphere in the office is too relaxing, people who don't have the right attitude may become lazy (That's why it is a place for newbies to learn)
*Only a few desks are developed. Some are completely undeveloped such as banking, finance, IT, Legal, Office Admin, etc
*BIGGEST PROBLEM
you can only do positions with monthly salary of $3x,xxx or below, others have to be passed to Spring Professional (recruitment firm also owned by Adecco Group). It means if your existing client contact you for candidates whose salary is above $3x,xxx, you can either reject your client or pass the opening to Spring Professional (Really discouraging)

pros: Adecco finally hired an on-site Program Manager after 2 1/2 years of my 3 (total years) contract. The Program Manager is amazing and provided resources that I never knew were available.
cons: I worked two separate contracts. My first contract was amazing. My recruiter was available and on-site. My second contract, I can't say the same. I started my second contract in one state and transferred to another state a few month in at my request. I questioned my "new" recruiter about filling out a new tax withholding form. He sent it, I filled it out, but apparently it was not submitted. Filing my taxes that year was a nightmare. Employee benefits ie. holiday pay and bonuses changed making it near impossible to track your eligibility. Employee handbook even states that Adecco has the right to change, not pay benefits at will (summarizing, not quoted). When work slowed down during my second contract I was laid-off for three months. I applied for unemployment benefits and was denied because Adecco reported that I quit, walked off the job and didn't report anything to my recruiter. I was brought back after 3 months and guaranteed a new contract (2 years). After 3 months I was informed that was not the case, even though the contract I signed was a new contract . My "newest" recruiter didn't even know when my last day on-site was. There has been no contact from recruiter since, even though I have inquired about other jobs in my area. I reached out to the Program Manager and was informed that there were none.

job_title: Client Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Benefits- medical and dental is fairly competitive, they match up to 3% of the 401k plan, and 18 days PTO
Management- This can vary a lot by team and region but I've been here 3 years and in two different roles and all my managers have been fantastic.  They seem to genuinely care about their teams and work hard to promote internally whenever possible.
Work/Life balance- Again, this probably varies quite a bit by region and branch.  However, I work in Silicon Valley where work /life balance in most companies is non-existent and in my experience this is something Adecco does well.  When employees have personal situations that require flexibility (small children, sick family members, long commutes, etc) they have worked hard to accommodate them.
cons: Salary- Pay is below market and it's caused some of their best employees to leave.  This puts a strain on current employees who are then left with added responsibility while new hires are trained.  It also makes it hard for Adecco to recruit experienced employees, so a lot of the employees are the branch level are brand new to staffing.

review_title: It is a good place to build a career, but get out as quickly as you can.
job_title: Technical Support Associate in Cincinnati, OH
pros: This is a great hands-on place to work if you can't find employment elsewhere. You can get experience at world renowned companies that you can't get anywhere else. This company is a stepping stone into a career. I especially recommend it to recent college or high school graduates.
cons:
The biggest downside is the complete lack of benefits. They claim to offer benefits, but they are so terrible that they're not even worth it. There are no sick days and only 6 vacation days per year, but they are so hard to get you almost never get paid for them. You must take no more than 5 days off in the previous 6 months and that may not be possible, depending on the site you work at. Some sites close down more frequently than others.

It was also implied to me that I could be hired at my place I contracted. Don't believe them! After 2 years of working in the same position I know its not true. 

Other advise: If you want a raise, request it. This company does not want good workers to go, but you have to go to them. Any incentives is like pulling teeth. Be on top of it.

review_title: What you see... May not always turn out to be what you get.
pros: The values and core principles of this organisation impressed me a lot. Since not many Indian companies imbibe such values in their everyday work culture. They believe in honesty and transparency between a senior and his subordinate and their clients. They believe in keeping work place politics a big hindrance to the growth of the employer, the employee as well as other stakeholders.
cons: However, the reality seemed to be far from this in the Indian subsidiary of Adecco. My experience in one of it's offices in the capital region was far from the picture I had created when I learn't about the 'values' the company holds. With respect to that particular branch where I worked for a little over a month, I observed a lot of office politics right from the week of my joining. This eventually led to attrition as employees (especially fresh graduates) don't find the environment healthy for their start.

review_title: Adecco’s writing the book on screwing people over.
job_title: Autonomous Vehicle Operator in Mountain View, CA
pros:
The only “pro” is you gain potential experience to move into a position at another company (off contract) and don’t have to worry about the ridiculous logics of contract companies.

Contract is with Waymo, you can get some decent knowledge even with the Great Wall if “Alphabet” up since you’re on a contract. The experience will get you into a better (all around) job doing some cool things.
cons:
- Extremely poor response times.
- Extremely poor responses (When you actually get one. Do they even read the emails? Listen on calls?)
- They like to flip things last minute (Bonus? Pay Increase? Expect delays, or additional deductions for their own pockets...)
- Constant email spam. No way to unsubscribe from their terribly formatted emails and newsletters.
- The hiring process from recruiter to the next 10 people who get dumped your file is lengthy, and cumbersome. You’ll be annoyed after the first week.
- If you have an issue with ANYTHING, expect an excuse on their end.
- 3 sick days per year, ...the flu lasts 7 days...
- Absolutely no PTO, no grievance time, nothing...
- Medical benefits are through Aetna (‘nuff said) and absurdly priced. Nearly $600/mo for an individual on a base plan (medical) with a $6k deductible. Hope you’re healthy.
- The job is boring. No one cares about you (literally).
- Absolutely no job security. You can and will be fired for just about anything.
- You’re a drone.
- Your voice goes to a black hole. Don’t expect opinions to matter. You’re temporary.

review_title: Customer service is NOT modeled at this agency
pros: I got hired- I had to go through them for the company that hired me
cons: Recruiters do not return phone calls. Upon arriving 10 minutes early for my "interview" (aka paperwork) I was asked to wait outside in the desert heat while they finished a meeting because they apparently did not have a space private enough to hold a meeting in. I was asked to come back a second time to finish up paperwork only to find that I had no paperwork to complete. Both times I went to the office my presence was barely acknowledged and I was not informed why I was waiting for 10-30 minutes while the recruiter I was to meet with finished other things. When I complained of the poor customer service the response I got was a lengthy explanation of what had occurred and ZERO apology. The closest the recruiter got to an apology was conceding that I was correct that they needed to improve their customer service. If I had not been hired for a specific agency I would not feel comfortable accepting work with companies Adecco works with because their lack of professionalism is a reflection of the companies they hire for.

This was a lie, as I was immediately place on 56+ hour mandatory work weeks. I was told that I would be direct hired by the company within 6 months which I was placed, and you guessed it this was also a lie as many other employees they placed in similar positions had been there with no change for at least one to two years. In the initial interview I was informed on very little regarding any of the details on this assignment as he literally sold me a pile of B.S., and also providing no preparation before I showed up my first day on the job. job_title: Quality Control in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: they try to motivate people by giving free stuff away to those who don't miss work or get employee of the month. You get paid weekly.
cons:
Adecco infantilizes its employees and micromanages down to the minute, literally. If you are 1 minute late, they will give you a tardy slip, as if you are in elementary school. There is an assumption on their part that workers will be lazy  (pro tip, not treating employees like crap is proven by studies to motivate productivity). You can only get their benefits after working there for about 6 months or a year (about 4 paid holidays, etc). Management is not good at resolving problems- they refused to figure out why direct deposit wasn't working for someone (likely someone on their end typed something in wrong) and tried to pressure her into getting an adecco card (she ended up just getting paper checks).  If you're 15 minutes late, they'll take a full hour off your pay (then you might as well just come in an hour late? stupid way to try to motivate people to be on time). Turnover is high, and they really don't give a crap about their workers since they can easily replace you with another unsuspecting (or desperate) individual.

Benefits are terrible and expensive. I ended up using the marketplace insurance to get decent coverage.

pros: Good culture chill withstand and game

pros:
Teri is a joy to work with--quick turn around, courteous, warm, patient. The other people in the Beaverton office are hard-working and pleasant. A lot of good humor in that office every time you come in! The website for Adecco proper has tons of online classes and how-to pages, fast sign up process if your documents are in order, and quick placement if you have relevant skills. When placed, Adecco gives full benefits and health insurance and takes care of HR issues for you, not necessarily the company whom you perform work for. 

If you are aware that Adecco's clients are companies who need workers, not you, and you are aware you must be a good "product" with skills for Adecco to place, negative reviews here make a lot more sense. You cannot be mad at Adecco that you did not get the job you want or you did not perform well at the job you got or you're not getting bites because the company did not want you--spiff up your resume and look up Adecco's classes on interviewing. Adecco's job is to align you to companies you might not have known were interviewing.
cons: Lengthy paperwork via a website, would have preferred to do that at home via email but I think I hadn't made myself clear before face-to-face. Mea culpa.

review_title: Management needs to display more trust.
job_title: Business Development Manager in Oak Brook, IL
pros: Coworkers are amazing. Base + comp plan is pretty good for the industry. Mandated hours are 8-5. Everyday is new and presents a different challenge when it comes to clients or candidates. Days go by pretty quick.
cons:
Manager has no understanding of how to trust his employees or express “proper” excitement for their achievements. The manager will say great job and then proceed what to do next as if you had no idea how to preserve the relationship YOU established with a client or candidate. The only people trusted in the office are the top performers and even then, they are micromanaged just to a lower degree. 

It’s very clear the manager is only interested in compensation at year’s end and has a set process to get to make sure he gets there. If it was up to me, the manager would be just a senior salesman with no management responsibilities. 

It’s a shame to say but if I had a different manager, I probably would’ve stayed because the job and the people I work with are so much fun.

review_title: At the the tipping point of going off the edge
pros: I gained good experience and was able to move on to a position paying the market value. Salaried position from the get go, so unlike other competitors you don't have to prove yourself.
cons: Stressful and Inept Management from the Top Down. Low pay - two other nationwide staffing competitors offer a salary (once you hit your goals) that is 8-10k more than Adecco's and a bonus structure that is MUCH more competitive. Horrible systems that do not talk to each other. Your job title is recruiter, but you are responsible for so much more from payroll to selling new business to workers compensation and so on. This makes it hard to do any one thing right. Turnover is astonishing at all levels of the organization. Pay is the lowest for comparable positions. Training is sink or swim. The direction  from top corporate executives is hazy besides, "we all need to work a little harder", but unfortunately everyone is maxed out.

pros: Not great place to work
cons: Avoid at all costs ok

review_title: I learned a lot, albeit without much support/help from my "peers" or from management for that matter, on my own.
job_title: Branch Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: The location in the city was great, no complaints there. It is a bigger, global company, so selling for them was a good experience because they should have SOP's had and sales training. Since they are larger in terms of employees, and with their large footprint, there are many ways to grow internallly, even to the point of moving to an emerging market. Great for a young professional!
cons: There was a lack of communication between management and reps, they enjoyed throwing newer guys to the wolves to train by fire, which is a great way to learn in sales, but a bit of hand-holding for new reps would go a long way towards building out a world-class tea.

pros: Adecco has great internal resources for those who are new to staffing. It's a great place to learn a lot about the industry. Branch Managers have P&L oversight and decision making authority for their branches.
cons: From my experience, branches in remote areas do not receive a lot of support from upper management. The company is in the process of changing KPIs and sales productivity requirements so it's a frantic environment right now. Expectations and new targets change constantly along with management. In a year, I had three different RVPs with three sets of expectations.  Rather than get help to meet your targets, you are simply penalized. Very frustrating most days, Also, there is no process in place to get help from management outside of your immediate  supervisor. Basically, you are at the mercy of a single individual with no way of sharing concerns with anyone else. It has not been a very rewarding experience.

pros: If you keep your head down you can stay out of the drama

review_title: The most fun I've had in the staffing industry thus far...
job_title: Staffing Consultant in San Jose, CA
pros: For me they offer a great work life balance, and a competitive salary between my base and commission structure.  The benefits are the best I've had since working for a multi-billion dollar Hi tech company, and praise is definitely given when its due.  The local management is very supportive, and offer their expertise whenever you need advice.
cons: Well in working in staffing, you always face adversity in the fact that it is very competitive.  You definitely feel the pressure to fill job orders and bill, however I feel that this is a neccessary evil in order to succeed.

pros: You get a ton of paid time off, that you never get to use! So it all rolls over, then you still can't use it the next year.
cons: They work you like dogs, to give jobs no one wants to people your competitors don't want to talk to. Not only do you have to work 10 hour days, but you get to work holidays as well! Have a family? Have a baby? Adecco doesn't care. As long as someone is sitting in their chairs to try to make them look good. And the best part is, you're making peanuts to do so. The benefits are crap, the only pro is they give you a ton of PTO knowing that you will never be able to take it. The only people they care about are senior management because they are taking 90% of the budget and putting it straight into their paycheck. The day I put in my notice was the best day of my life, and no one even acknowledged I did so until a week later.

pros: Sadly none at all.
cons: Please see below- Far too many to list.

review_title: Looks good from afar, but get close & you'll see the ugly.
pros:
- Great learning opportunities.
- Solid foundation to kick off my career.
- Enough of a budget to actually do really fun marketing-based initiatives
cons:
Upper management in my department was awful and very much based on politics. One MARRIED man in particular - still there I might add - had an alcohol problem that would very much affect other employees. If he was drinking at an after work function or a work dinner/event, he would become inappropriate to female colleagues - including me at one point. He's faced a talking to from HR once for lewd behavior & yet, he still has a job & sits on the leadership team.

I felt like leadership did not have the best intentions for employees. They often claimed to be transparent, but rarely were. Only for the first year did I ever really feel "safe" in my job, then when I saw three people in our department get fired in one day (very obviously and during the middle of the day), I got very anxious & nervous. Many of us did. The dynamic changed.

I'm glad I got the work experience I did, but I do not miss that place. At all.

pros: yearly winners trip scheme, commission, lots of incentives and good training & good company culture.
cons:
it is soul destroying being spoken to badly by clients when you are trying to help them, candidates always let you down and hound you, having to compete with so many different agencies becomes exhausting, getting candidates in just to hit KPIs and then not being able to find them a job, I paid my own expenses for months and didn't get them paid back so buying muffins and chocolates with my own money for clients and then having them talk to you badly and not appreciating it ended up making me resent it. 

no lunch breaks, 
late nights and weekends, absolutely no work life balance - having to take calls and organize shifts in the evening if you do temps.

review_title: Should change name to What-A-Mess, not Modis
pros: Good co-workers but they will fire/lay-off the good ones quickly so don't get used to it.  Depending on who you are/job function/location, you don't have to work too hard and you have no supervision so it is a great place for those people.
cons: Poor recruiter training/expectations, bad (worse than poor) management with lots of changes, archaic website and marketing department, no support for sales at all,  when 1 division does poorly, they lay-off/fire people to balance every month to 6 weeks.  Inconsistent vision means you may be hired for something and re-diverted entirely.

pros: You get a paycheque each week so you are able to pay rent and eat.  The odd time you meet someone who turns out to change your life for the better.
cons:
The company has no appreciation for people working in the branches, it is all about the all mighty dollar..."make money...no matter how unethical you treat people".  Sr. Management is comprised of those people who lacked the self esteem to walk away from a company that bases their promotions on your butt kissing skills.  Education is irrelevant, if you are not capable of making a decision, treating people with integrity or forming a unique opinion of a situation than this is the company for you.

Perfect example....during economical challenges this company took 5% of their employees salary right across the board....then they used this savings to buy another company to make their leaders more money...and how many people thought that this was wrong and left...not too many...they are conditioned to "follow the leader"...good or bad and therefore will go down with this sinking ship!

pros: None. No benifits no holiday pay in fact no pay of any kind.
cons: Bad customers service. Lack of advancement. Soul sucking work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Merritt Island, FL
pros:
- Overtime is usually available when you want it
- Most of the people I worked with were cool
- When they made you work overtime during holidays they would buy pizza (but it was cold and tasted disgusting)
cons:
- Salary (the pay is not commensurate with what is expected)
- Training is inconsistent with what really takes place on the floor
- Mandatory scheduled overtime (they choose it for you)
- They would cancel breaks when calls were high (even if people had been working 6+ hours without a break). 
- Serious lack of communication
- Inconsistent policies and procedures

Supervisors are present to oversee the floor, guide/instruct phone agents in unfamiliar situations, etc. but a lot of the time they would tell you to do things you have already done, pawn off the calls to someone else or make you take the call even if the customer has already stated, requested or screamed for a supervisor.

review_title: They stick you in a sweat shop
job_title: I Don't Even Know in Raleigh, NC
pros: They really don't care if you have skills or not, they just want bodies that show up. You don't even have to show up on time, they'll still let you work. If you're a smooth fast talker, they'll believe any excuse you tell them.
cons: Work is sporatic at best. When there is work it's 12 hour shifts with two 15 minute breaks and a half hour lunch. They make you wear steel toes even though you just stand in one place the whole time. They don't care if you have skills to do a certain job, you will do the job that takes no skills. there is no advancement, you will not get hired on the the company. The only time you see the Adecco supervixor is for 5 minutes per day when he comes areound to tell everyone what time to show up if there is work the next day. You may show up for work and be told that you were laid off by the supervisor of the compnay you are assigned to.

job_title: Customer Service in Eau Claire, WI
pros: Long term staff were very caring, courteous, and professional.
cons: I filled out a form for direct deposit.  I inquired for over a month about why my pay was being sent as a check through the mail.  Finally I called and got on the line with Adecco's newly hired office assistant.  I asked her to read my checking account number in their payroll system back to me.  Someone at Addeco had entered it incorrectly.  I slowly and carefully reiterated the account numbers back to her.  She notified me that it had been successfully updated and went in to closing the call; however, I interrupted her and asked her to reiterate my account number back to me.  This back and forth was repeated five more times until she finally got the number entered correctly.  Later, I came down with the flu, and called in to notify that I would be out for a couple days.  I was excused for the first day because the new Adecco employee  marked me down as excused for the day I called in only.  The subsequent days were marked as a "No Call - No Show," and I was told, after the end of this assignment, I could not work for Adecco for 2 years because of it.

job_title: Enterprise Delivery Recruiter in Vancouver, WA
pros: Adecco has been a wonderful company to work for so far.    They try to ensure that not only the employees have job satisfaction but also the associates (temps).  The fact that Adecco is a global company is sometimes lost, because they have it segmented so well that you feel like you're a apart of a small team that supports everything you do, rather than a huge cooperate conglomerate .  I have worked for many organizations throughout my career and I will say that Adecco ranks among the top.   They make sure I have all of the tools and training I need to be successful in my role.  I am happy to come to work everyday for a company that helps me develop personally and professionally.
cons: Sometimes processes can be lengthy when you might need a quick answer.  Usually it is because there are multiple departments that are involved.

pros: Benefits are solid at adecco
cons: Communication from management needs work.

pros: Great company for those trying to break into an HR role. You will get inundated with information and experience that will make getting into an HR Generalist role much easier. Don't plan on being here for more than three years - see cons. Use the experience to get something better down the road.
cons: If you're looking for a long-term career, use caution. This is a large company and they treat you as such. Tenure and accomplishments mean little in the way of sales today. Upper management is hidden behind a fake mask of caring. This is not the company for someone not willing to get ahead by stabbing others in the backs.

review_title: Terrible company won't pay me for hours that I've worked already.
pros: Absolutely none this has been the worst experience I've had with a staffing company.
cons: if I could give zero stars I would. I worked for them doing an event and they screwed up my check. They lied and told me I would have it Yesterday then they lied and said today by the end of business then back tracked at the end of the business day and said payroll said it would have it done in 24 hours. When I asked them why they lied to me they took no responsibility for there actions and blamed everything on payroll. I called them serveral times about my check today and they lied to me all day saying it would be done today. The manager lied and said I called and yelled at her staff all day which was false I had been very calm especially considering they are playing with my money. Then when I got upset for them lying to me all day the manager started yelling at me and hung up in my face terrible company I never want to work for them again I just want my money which it looks like I will have to call the state and get them involved because they keep lying to me.

pros: Adecco is great for military spouses because of the global reach and number of locations. The shorter tenured staff teams work ideally for frequent change.
cons: Staff turnover is high on every level of employment and management.  Compensation is less than competitive. Hours and expectations are unrealistic. All locations need additional support staff to manage locations effectively. The company boasts on training /growth opportunities and paid time off, but the staff is too minimal to capitalize on either.

review_title: Experience varies widely depending on location.
pros:
Variety of *entry*level* jobs, great for jacks-of-all-trades.
Great for students, fill-in jobs, seasonal employment, summer work, etc.
Good connections to local job community; often many opportunities (not always).
cons:
--Several different positions are usually available, but many people vying for them.  Often overly-qualified applicants (such as myself, with nearly 100% on all tests) with lower experience in available fields are left doing $8/hour foodservice fill-in jobs with no explanation.
--Have to sometimes pry 'minimum rate' advice from associates (balance skills/experience with minimum requested income rate to enhance prospects) -- I've been badly advised on more than one occasion, and been passed over for perfectly acceptable jobs that were very close to but under my minimum.

pros: If you have experience its a good opportunity because the staff is not really good "recruiting". So if you actually have done recruiting is a very simple job.
cons: The higher management team is very old school and needs to bring new blood that can bring new ideas and motivate the staff. If they hired better recruiters in the temp team that at least had college degrees, the sales/profit would increase and so would the level of service. Things have changed and its important to improve with the times. The old Rolodex mentality is not current...I think this is why probably the pricing is so low. No opportunity for growth employees keep the same position for up to 20 years with the same compensation and the commissions are a joke.

review_title: It's a good company but it has a lot of room for improvement.
pros:
Great benefits. I work with a great team (this is very personal and micro), but something that I love. Good work-life balance. I usually work 40 hours per week. Maybe 10 times I've had to work overtime in the past 1.6 years.

It is important to note that Adecco is a company that keeps you busy. There is always work... way more work than one can handle.
cons:
Sometimes leadership is unresponsive and does not follow up with promises (especially relating to promotions, salary increases, projections, among other things).
Adecco chooses to work with many clients that do not treat their employees well. This makes a recruiter's job harder, since you're offering a job that is not good with a company that usually has a reputation that is obvious when researching online.
CEO pressence is also non-existent.

review_title: Educational Testing Services AP Reading Project
job_title: Files Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Some of the best things about this job is that you are able to meet many different people and learn how to communicate, and work with, those many different kinds of people. This job is not mentally taxing, but is not necessarily easy for those who dislike rote work. You can have a lot of down-time while you are waiting for the readers to finish grading essays, but you can also be working around the clock if they are grading quickly. This makes things nice because, as the days are extremely long, the varying pace mixes things up. You also get free lunch and snacks every day, which helps offset not being compensated for parking.
cons: You are working with the same group of people all week long, ten hours per day; if you do not have co-workers that you like, this can be difficult. Flexibility is a must for this job. Sometimes, things become very monotonous, and you  might not get to work the entire duration of your scheduled days, as all of the exams will inevitable be finished being graded before the last day.

pros: Has some long term assignments.
cons: Little pay for lots of work.  The employers they place you with take advantage of you and treat you like a second class citizen.  Their 1800 bonus sucks.  Used to be $400 which is a weeks pay, now it is like 2.5% of your gross pay.  You never get paid for holidays even though they claim you do.  Basically you have to not miss one day of work in order to qualify for holidays.  It always seems as if they change their policies when it is convenient for them and do not notify their employees.

review_title: Accept it with an open mind
pros: Here is a great way to meet new people and see how many companies work.  A great networking job.  No matter how bad (or good) it gets, the job is temporary.
cons: Sometimes I felt that I was on my own.  The people in companies you are assigned to take advantage of a temp.  Expect to work hard be paid one of the least salaries in a company you are assigned.  The permanent employees give you their work above and beyond the job you signed up for while they make personal phone calls and chat with each other. If you discuss it with your Adecco liaison, you will be asked if you want to leave the assignment.  Once you bring up a concern, you will be overlooked for other assignments.

pros: Good benefits and PTO that starts accruing immediately.  Ample opportunities for professional growth and development. Company size makes changing your career to a different department more feasible. Culture is warm and very family-friendly. Good work/life balance. Employees and leaders treat each other with respect and dignity always.
cons: Due to the company's size, there are organizational difficulties that make doing your everyday job more challenging than it needs to be. It is not uncommon for a corporate department to take more than a week to respond to an urgent email or not to respond at all, or to respond with "that's not my job" and no one to tell you whose job it is. There are always forms and approvals needed that take multiple steps and days to get small tasks done so you can feel like your hands are tied at times.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Muncie, IN
pros:
I. Employee's receive their paychecks. 
II. The company is willing to provide additional hours. 
III. Employee's are paid $12 an hour.
cons:
I. Management isn't the best. 
II. Too many chiefs to Indians. Management to normal staff ratio. 
III. No benefit's. 
IV. High turnover rate among new hires/ current employee's. 
V. Adecco tend's to side with the contracted company in employee disputes. 
VI. Employee's are trained in things that won't apply to them. 
VII. Employee's are held to high standards and accountable for things that is out of their control. That includes unnecessary disciplinary action. 
VIII. Employee's are disciplined for faulty software that the company provides. 
IX. Management tends to shift their responsibilities onto the staff. 
X. Employee's are docked points during training. 
XI. Team leaders is undependable.

review_title: Work at Adecco, Make your mistakes then make a lot more money somewhere else
pros: They are the Largest Staffing Agency in the World. The people who work there at the staff level are usually great people to work with.
cons: Zero training aside from the a basic training of 3 days and a additional 3 day HIT training.  You are set up to fail with no support from management.  Directors have never ran a Direct Hire desk before.  I found this out by another recruiter who left the company.  They were managers of Temp offices but not perm.  You are on an island to bring in your own business.  There is no cross selling between business units.  I worked there for a couple of years and never received a job order flipped to me from the temp side or got an order from a corporate account.  Their benefits are embarassing!  For a $29 billion dollar company its sad!

review_title: Terrible benefits and very limited holiday and time off pay
pros: The agency staff are friendly but there is not much else I can say that is good about this company.
cons: It wasn't until a year after I had worked for them that someone reached out to me to ask how my assignment was going. No one followed up after the first 30 to 60 days which I find to be alarming. The benefits are absolutely the worst you will find compared to other agencies. Vacation pay is non existent depending on your contract and they make holiday pay a major runaround, it was explained to me differently three times. I've been working for them for over a year and have yet to receive any holiday pay. There is no such thing as sick time so if you have to take time off for medical reasons kiss your holiday pay goodbye.

review_title: Okay for the first step into recruiting. But NOT a place to grow old with
pros: I worked with a lot of great people. We had a team of great recruiters. My direct boss was okay. However, her boss and the higher ups did not genuinely care about their employees.
cons: Started as a temp to hire position. I was one of the top performers on the team and even met with several executives high up in the company to show them the ins and outs of our division. However, I was not converted to a permanent employee which meant no benefits, PTO or any good perks that came along with it.

review_title: Life as a Branch Manager for Adecco
pros: Adecco is a large organization that has a number of career tracks depending on your interest.  One of the other great things is that you could potentially relocate to various places around the U.S. (and world for that matter) and still stay employed with the organization.
cons: I never felt like the most Sr. Management was interested in the local markets.  That's to say, in the two years that I worked for them, I did not once have leadership above the RVP level visit our local office.  This, for me and the recruiters that worked for me, was a bit disappointing.  The only other issue if you like feeling connected to the company you work for was that with such a large organization, people can get lost in the crowd.  Local management was awesome, but in the big scheme of things, you knew that you were but a small entity on a large island.

review_title: It's what you make of it
pros: There is room for growth and your manager will map out how to get there and steps needed to take to get there. My manager was hands down the best manager I have ever had the pleasure of working with and was the reason I stayed for as long as I did. Great health benefits, 19 days PTO when you start out, 401K, stock options, managers are willing to work with your schedules.
cons: The directors and VP's say they care about the colleagues but their actions speak very differently! No holiday parties, no annual increases,  low pay for the work you are expected to do, you have to bend over backwards to get your settlement fees, the candidates you work with are one of a kind (not in a good way).

pros: Adecco is a global HR solutions provider so having global network and opportunities is fabulous.  You get to work with clients who you may not necessarily get to work with if you are in a small boutique agency as many of these clients prefer global businesses.  The brands across Staffing, Pontoon, LHH, Ajilon, Judd Farris, Beeline - are all great brands to represent.  Adecco is a fun place to work where we have great colleagues, and they allow a degree of flexibility for work life integration.
cons: Change is a constant - so you must be resilient.  I have been at Adecco for 4 years and have had amazing opportunities to develop and grow.  Changes in management always lead to structural changes.

review_title: Lots of opportunity stifled by inconsistency between message of leaders and actions of leaders and their direct reports.
job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The colleagues who are employed by the company are top-quality. They are helpful, informative, knowledgeable, and overall very friendly. If you take a few minutes to walk around and introduce yourself, they are so willing to be open and help you in the future.
cons: Leadership has no concept in corporate of their silos or how to change. They don't realize that their actions speak louder than their words and "silent" struggles between SVPs are not going unnoticed or ignored by the colleagues. Sending a message of "this is how we want to be" doesn't erase the months of watching power plays between leaders, especially those between new upper-level executives and old-time 10-years-plus-tenured senior leaders.

pros: None as far as I could see.  They are as misleading and unprofessional as they come.  Avoid at all costs.
cons:
I was invited to apply in person for an engineering position that I was well qualified for.  The receptionist told me that I needed to "get into the system" and directed me to a computer cubby to register my personal info.  Upon completion of filling out my name, address, etc I was prompted to take a variety of personality and character tests that felt more oriented toward a 2nd grader than an educated professional.  It took an hour or so to complain their tasks.   At that time I was told the position they instructed me to come to their office to discuss was filled.  I was then offered a $10/hr technician job on the spot.  I respectfully declined and explained that I couldn't support my family on a salary like that, to which i was told "That's the going rate".  
I suggest anyone with any amount of self respect avoid this company like the plague.

pros: You get the job the next day and that's the only pro I can think off
cons: You don't receive your pay and you can constantly phone (on the number they give you on your day 0)  then and they will keep saying we will look into it and get back to you, they never phone back and no matter how often you harass them you can go weeks without pay, the head office phone number is a duff (if you try phone then it will just ring out). It looks like Adecco doesn't have the money to pay there staff or it's a con, if you want to work at Amazon I advise you go with PMP, I myself am still waiting for my pay from the last few weeks though Adecco and don't seem to be getting anywhere and I have been phoning the giving number (01383 749505)  everyday time and time again and they keep saying we will phone you back yet never do, I have also been going to there office in Amazon and had no luck there. The best way to get your pay is take legal action. If you are going with Adecco or with Adecco currently good luck.

review_title: Weak leadership, unrealistic expectations, unaccountable management.
job_title: Permanent Placement Consultant in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros:
Good perks: massage sessions in the office, fruit day, great tea and coffee, the occasional flexi time during the summer (one Friday off per month), professional support staff.
Low base salary, good performance incentives.

I was placed on a project by Adecco, a staffing firm I truly enjoyed. The registration process is easy and parts of it was virtual which I really liked. I didn't have to go to the office several different times to complete the process. 
My account manager Kate Schoenfeld was outstanding, she understood my needs and what I was looking for. My first assignment turned into a permanent gig after 2 years.
cons: One hugh downside to working with Adecco and still is a issue is they don't reach out to their contractors who they place. Currently we have several other contractors working with us and they have not heard from Adecco. Not once have they checked in to ask how the assignment is going? I would think they would want to know from their contractors, right?

pros: It's an ok starting place to a career in human resources. You are responsible for doing EVERYTHING so it gives you a chance to understand what you don't like, and what you want to continue on with in another company. The benefits are good.
cons: #Adecco is a #greatplacetowork if you want to be over worked, under paid, and under appreciated. You should also be comfortable teaching yourself because there is minimal training for new hires; you'll do a few videos and call it a day. You should not be a person who can form your own opinions and don't you dare ask questions; this is a 'be quiet and drink the kool-aid' place. Also, don't let the PTO woo you - it's like a punishment taking a day off; nothing gets done and you work OT to catch up. Speaking of OT, you're salaried and work more than 40 hours every week...

review_title: Worst hiring-and-interviewing practices ever- for menial, tedious jobs.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: They set a perfect example of how automated hiring and recruiting tactics drive away top talent and should be turned out to pasture. Oh, and I did get a little customer service position out of them, which I was promised would be a stepping stone to something better that they could find for me. Which they didn't. Glad I left when I did.
cons: Everything else. It took like a month and hours on top of hours to go through a whole slew of ridiculous tests- all to get a job answering a phone! Also, they treat recruits really rudely, as if your time and efforts aren't worth anything. They don't communicate at all and leave you hanging about whether you have/have not been hired for weeks at a time. Since it is a staffing agency I am half-tempted to tell their clients as a courtesy that it is Adecco which is preventing them from getting good hires. This company is only worth bothering with if you are desperate for any job just to get you through.

pros:
I'm currently employed through Adecco, but my current contract is about to expire/up for renewal. I've had the chance to experience a lot of different job duties and atmospheres and beef up my resume with real experience and skills.
With my former rep., I was able to find jobs that exposed me to a variety of work environments and cultures, even when friends of mine were having trouble getting a foot in the door.
cons: My former Adecco rep. resigned her position a few months ago, and while I know the name of the new rep., I have neither met with nor spoken to her. I got an email from a separate Adecco rep., but after replying to her and sending in my resume, I haven't heard a thing.

pros: As for the pros the only one I would say is the companies they hire put too are more career driven
cons: Took 2 months the to get hired on. Been here 3 weeks no paycheck.  They lied to me multiple times. Would never recommend anyone to work here

pros:
Weekly Pay

Job Choice

More than minimum wage

Jobs for experienced and inexperienced both

Clients often overhire and as such laborers can rest more between work.
cons:
Paid two weeks after a job not in the same week of said job.

Lack of work for inexperienced/non-skilled workers

(About 3 to 4 jobs a month when you first start it seems)

Experience required jobs hinder skilled employee's from gaining said jobs. A cycle of 1-3 years experience minimum stopping skilled workers from gaining said 1-3 years of required experience.

pros: Excellent benefits - 18 days PTO when you start, 5 days bereavement, decent health insurance, dental and vision insurance too!  Good home/work balance.
cons: No growth potential, very corporate and upper management run.  Branch managers are not given flexibility to run branches like their own business, despite being told to do so.  Management does not listen to problems at the branch level, short staffed.  Pay is not competitive.

pros: Great place to start your career in the recruitment business. Strong sales focus and excellent training scheme. Team focused with ownership to shared goals and targets. You also learn a lot about business and get a great opportunity to build a nice customer portfolio for use in your next jobs.
cons:
Not a place to be if you want to make money through strong sales results. Bonuses are capped and the branch results has a direct impact on your pay checks, despite your own results. We had a sales team of 5 and I was pulling 50-65% of the total sales in my branch and never got a bonus. Annoyed me so I moved on.
High turnover is an issue in Adecco, and could easily be dealt with if staff was encouraged via other incentives than the 25y.o. style jolly trips etc..

pros:
Knowledgeable representatives eager to fill positions and with quick turn around times.  If I email my rep. with a question I will most likely receive a message back within the next 24 hours - even on weekends/holidays.

Can get into facilities with exciting opportunities that are only open to the agency.

Good pay.

Weekly pay.
cons:
Benefits aren't so great and PTO is very difficult (i.e. nearly impossible) to earn - including paid holidays.  If you have to take time off - which you do if you are sick or the facility you are assigned to closes for holidays - you have to be able to deal with not getting paid for that time.

Job uncertainty is a constant as the agency is not very communicative about expected outlook/timeframe on job placements (somewhat to be expected given that this is basically temp agency that we are talking about and they probably don't always have the answer either.)

pros:
I worked in the NYC location, and one of the biggest pros was working for Tonya Lain who is an absolutely fantastic VP. She takes the time to get to know everyone, and sits out on the floor with the team, and would treat the team to Thai Friday's as well. Just a great person, and overall leader. 

Your PTO starts off at 18 days. 

Friendly team, collaborative environment. 

Allow you to take on new projects - good for entry level role, first job out of college. 

Fantastic worklife balance. If your hours were 8:30am - 5:30pm, that was what you were working.
cons:
Computer technology was pretty behind, systems were always slow and a lot of them only worked on Internet Explorer. 

Some of the managers were not the nicest to deal with, stressful to work under. 

Very much a sales environment, which might be what others are looking for. 

Not much room for growth, as their offices just moved to Florida and the main offices still in NY are recruiting only.

review_title: signed up for Adecco to find me a job
pros: Charlotte really nice  friendly person made you feel at ease
cons: Lied to many people who signed up to them to work at Amazon. Promised 9 months worth guaranteed  in October  all day staff laid off  first week in Jan  contatnly sent home as  no work  up to  three weeks before we left  treated you as a number didnt care if you had bills to pay house to run. All they were interested in was getting the  numbers in  for Amazon  so they looked good  didn't care they were dealing with peoples lives  .Some people  had left jobs to work there on the basis it was full time for 9months. When you rung Bolton office  got an arsy  woman on phone Dillion  didn't care just stated nowt to do with me speak them up there put phone down rude arrogant  woman

review_title: I saw some kind of illegal practices
pros: The benefits of working at Adecco are basically the things that are good about working as a temp. It's hard to think of what those are.
cons:
I encountered some hostility and belittlement when I sought an ADA accommodation. There was nothing explicite or illegal about that but here are some things that are:
- Male managers were paid more than  female managers.
- When my coworkers talked about that among  one another, an Adecco rep announced to our whole team that if anyone was caught discussing their pay with coworkers they would be fired. 
- At a company where my friend worked, Adecco was contracted to assist with hiring. When arranging an interview with one deaf person, they asked the person to bring their own interpreter. Law mandates that Adecco would have to provide the interpreter in this situation.

pros: Good resources/tools introduced in the last 18 months.  The restructure moving headquarters to Jacksonville Fl resulted in a much more responsive, service oriented corporate team.  Lots of autonomy in the role to design your own approach and create a positive culture in your own space.  Great support from immediate management with lots of expertise available!
cons: Like most organizations constant change is a means of survival!  Some changes could be better vetted/tested before roll out to prevent confusion and frustration.  It's important to get onboard with management's decision quickly.  Not much room for differences of opinion or pointing out the holes in a new idea etc...

job_title: Software Engineer II in Boise, ID
pros:
They hired me.
I am an "older" tech worker. They are willing to hire Engineers who are not in the prime age group of 20 - 27. Yay!
Hourly - you don't get told to come in on weekends unless you are getting 1.5x time.
If you get in the right place, you will enjoy your job even if you are underpaid.
cons:
I'm really working for HP. But HP outsources a lot of work locally. They play the various contracting agencies off one another to get engineers at the lowest price. So HP gets what they pay for in the end.
No real benefits. They are offered but not worth the price. 
Very weird working in an environment where you are considered a second class citizen (not Adecco's fault).

pros: Wonderful teams - if you thrive in a positive work environment with great people this is a great workplace.  I enjoyed working with teams from all over Canada and the training was great.
cons:
If you are tight on cash, the first 3 months are brutal.  This is due to having to wait 3 months minimum before you see any commission.  Once you get through the 3 months, it is ok.
Small office means you also do double duty.  I could not be successful at my job as a recruiter while being told I needed to man the door because we needed a minimum of 2 people in an office of 3 at all times.

review_title: Great place to start out and a bad place to end with.
job_title: Account Executive in San Diego, CA
pros: It's a very large company so they do have the infrastructure in place to withstand tough economic changes.
cons: The branch I was in was in had poor leadership. Because base salaries are fairly low, they mostly hire people with little or no experience so they don't have an understanding of the candidates that they're recruiting or the client's needs. They let the branch managers have a lot of control so it can be quite personal and if you don't go along with everything they say then you can be ostracized. Not a very professional environment. It's hard to fill more complicated positions when you don't have good recruiters. They don't train the recruiters to research so they just rely on job boards for everything.

review_title: Adecco Honda; great company when you actually start
pros: They offer great benefits, pay is well, you gain raises after a certain set of hours as well as call off days, there are holidays that you get off, and there are programs you can enroll in to get paid more if you're accepted.
cons: The onboarding process is VERY INCONVENIENT. I had to push back very important payments because I still haven't been contacted concerning my start date after completing very lengthy testing and their orientation. Both the Honda office and the Adecco office were also very rude when I inquired about this. Going in for orientation the Honda office was also a bit cold and unwelcoming.

pros:
-Global name recognition
-Leader in staffing and recruiting industry
-Solid financial standing 
-9 to 5. No weekends
cons: My branch manager was awesome. However, district manager was not. Snobby, self absorbed, power tripped manager. Be ready to Kiss up to them or they'll find a reason to get rid of you. Most branch employees dread their overly "high maintenance" visits. Be ready to pretend you love them and can't hardly wait for  them to come back...On the job training by completing a series of pass or fail modules, have to be up to speed immediately given that you will quickly be evaluated on your ability to bring in new clients ASAP. Co is too large for its own good. You'll never meet upper management, impersonal, feeling like you are a number.

review_title: It calls itself an MNC, but actually works like a local company. Only business oriented org.
pros: Less politics, Sat- Sun off, Timely salary payment thats it. Good for Learning as one person is expected to do 2 people work,
cons: Don't trust this co on incentives, Job insecurity, layoffs, No strategic management, All depends on Management decisions, Boasts of values but lives nothing, poor salary, no growth, no salary hikes in last 2 years, if they give it is peanuts, Rs. 500 can also be given as hike. Attrition rate very high.

job_title: Client Program Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: If you work hard and take initiative, management will help you grow and seek new challenges. Coworkers are really fun! We go out to happy hour on a monthly basis of we meet goals. Regional meeting allow employees throughout the area connect.
cons: The actual job duties can be frustrating and draining. The expectation is to do it all for not nearly enough pay. Each branch operates independently and takes financial hits while corporate still reaps the benefits of success. There is a disconnect between Corporate expectations and the reality of dealing with the day-to-day in the branch. It's difficult to deal with unreliable clients and candidates. There is high turn-over and it doesn't seem to be a concern. People can only take so much before they look elsewhere and each branch makes cuts at the beginning of the year.

review_title: Solid Contractor with no career development
pros: My experience with Adecco was good overall. It was my first and only time working as a contractor so I have no other jobs to compare it to. I was fortunate to have a great project in an incredible working environment. I found Adecco's reps to be very responsive to my questions and needs; the hourly wage was at the high end of the pay scale amongst other contractors for the same position; and the company appeared to have a solid working relationship with the project company.
cons: These are probably standard for contractors but the biggest cons included: no benefits, no employer matching for the 401k, contract-based work (not Adecco's fault), and no career development. And I didn't feel like Adecco would find me work elsewhere had my contract not been renewed consistently.

review_title: Where are all these great jobs Adecco advertises?
pros: Adecco has a pretty comprehensive benefits package, if it's something you're interested in. In my case, they had a job waiting for me whenever I applied and talked to an agent. The pay rates for jobs through Adecco, at least the ones I've had the pleasure of noting, were a bit higher than minimum wage.
cons: There is little room for advancement or securing a full-time stable job. Also, Adecco advertises for jobs that have a great pay and room for advancement, but I've only found strictly temporary jobs with lower pay than Adecco advertises. Also, when my first Adecco assignment was done, they continued to advertise that jobs were available in local media, however they told me that there weren't any clients hiring at that time.

pros: Able to wrap up the day and not have to take additional work home with you
cons: Understaffed in the branch leaving the recruiter to act as both a receptionist and a recruiter at the same time. This leaves almost no time to take a much needed break in what ends up being over a 9 hour work day. As a salaried employee there is no overtime and the pay is extremely low for the work load and the expectations of corporate. The branch manager did very little to provide even part time support to assist with answering phones and assisting potential hires with paperwork or questions about the computer system. The local area managers should be more in touch with the needs of specific branches in order for them to be successful and meet the goals set for each recruiter.

pros:
You gain a lot of exposure to various levels of client management and on site management
Supportive team when handling client and associate care
Pretty good hours when you are managing client/team
Company wants to be more innovative and competitive, which means there is change constantly
cons:
Challenges when moving if you are not "in"
More likely to be in same role for many years with limited exposure
A lot of tenure in senior positions which sometimes turns into "let's do it how we know it"

pros: I worked as a contractor assigned to a client company. Within Adecco there were no regular performance reviews.
cons:
There where no regular performance reviews, which means if you're working for Adecco then you'll likely continue receiving the same pay for the entire time be months or years.  Also there are no cost of living increases.

In my case I knew my bill rate was 65% more than what I was earning, Yet Adecco management clung to the idea that there was no room for a cost-of-living increase even after 5 years of continuous service.

If looking to be hired by Adecco then during the hiring negotiations pad your earning requirements accordingly.

Holidays are only paid if you average > 38 hours per week for the previous 6 months. Overtime does not get included in this calculation. Time off for vacation also kills your average.

review_title: They treated us like criminals and kindergarteners, but I liked the actual work
job_title: Long-Term Temp Employee for Big Deal Client
pros: I found the work interesting, enjoyable and meaningful. In particular, we could listen to books and music while working, which was great.  The material we worked with was often very interesting to me. Since it was a temp agency, you could ask for another assignment if it didn't work out.
cons: Job was classified office, but it was more like a factory job.  They monitored our time and output very stringently.  Getting time off was often very difficult. I even heard a story about someone who asked for time off to attend a funeral 1 or 2 days later. The site supervisor said, "Next time give us more notice." Like you know 2 weeks in advance that someone's going to die. Site supervisor was cold, uncaring, rude and semi-literate. She literally couldn't spell personnel.  Staff morale was often low.

pros: They have access to jobs that aren't posted publicly. Pay is weekly. I have to say they found work for me when I really needed it.
cons: No communication from the office. They rarely call to find out how you are liking the job or if you would like to look for a change. Benefits are too costly and coverage poor. Office doesn't seem very supportive.

job_title: Account Executive in New York, NY
pros:
Fortune 500 company

Great clients

Nice office space
cons:
Unprofessional account excutives and Sr. leadership

Highly bureaucratic, unorganized, and extremely unproductive

Takes advantage of new sales team, by making them recruit candidates without compensation (We are not recruiters, we're sales professionals)

Bad attitudes and mistreatment from certain Sr. staff

Sr. team are not the smartest people to work with, however, the office VP is very nice and professional

A few junior account executives are not well-trained before coming into Adecco, nor are they prepared for corporate level positions

Very high-turnover (Office culture needs work, and Sr. team needs restructuring)

Terrible candidate reviews on Yelp and Google reviews.

review_title: A good company to work for if you like gaps in employment.
pros: The staff at Adecco is very friendly and work with you in order to ensure you are satisfied with your temporary assignment.
cons: The amount of assignments you receive are lacking. One assignment will end and you may not receive another long term position for two weeks.  This gap is tough when you are living check to check. I'd say this is the case for most temporary workers for Adecco from my experiences. The staff has explained these gaps may be caused by the economy slowing down and the time of year. The only thing they can offer is small one to two day assignments moving boxes of files around. Overall I am not impressed and am looking for other temporary agencies to work for until I have completed my B.S. in Business administration

pros: The work environment in most positions is pretty easy going. Management tends to defend your job, and fight for you when necessary. You get good experience working here and there are plenty of opportunities to move up and even laterally if desired. They pay a decent wage for most jobs. There is a decent amount of time off too, and are very flexible if you need time off.
cons: Health coverage is weak. If you work as a contractor for Adecco, you can feel like a second class citizen to the actual employee's of where you are working. Layoff's are always looming too. Keep that resume up to date!

review_title: Inept Wreck of a Staffing Agency
pros: Found me a good job quickly
cons: Radio silence when I needed help/advice on Adecco policies and information about my PTO.  The first agent who I was in contact with  quit and I got no notification, not even an out of office email so that I could know to contact someone else.  The same exact thing happened a few months later with the second agent.  The third was so utterly oblivious and unhelpful, clearly had no idea how to do the job, and is now the only one working in that office.  It's truly a travesty how much money this company profited off my work without providing anything but a few hours of job searching at the beginning of my contract.  I've called multiple other offices that are not managing my case, and they've been much more helpful, but the fact that the office that has access to all my files and notes can't even bother to call me back is ridiculous.

pros: They paid me on time every week. After I had been at same assignment for 3 years my PTO time went from 5 to 10 days a year. Five paid holidays a year after I think it was 6 months.
cons: When I needed them to help me when I was looking to get the 3rd party health insurance, they let me down. Was away on vacation when the 7 - 10 day sign up period came. Asked for help from on site Adecco office and got little to no help. I had to keep at them all the time. Was trying to get an exemption to get insurance in Feb 2015 and was refused. Told to wait until Nov - Dec sign up period.

review_title: You're contract could end at any time, and they won't give you an honest reason why
job_title: Underpaid Underappreciated Temp in Hoffman Estates, IL
pros:
You can get holiday pay after 1200 consecutive hours worked (within 26 weeks).
They'll arrange (free of charge) to collect all your personal belongings that you left in your desk, because you had no idea that your assignment was ending until after you left for the weekend (see below).
cons:
Pay scale on lower end for trained technical workers.
No free benefits (however, you can elect to pay exorbitant rates for substandard coverage).
Even though your contract has just been extended for seven months, about a week or two later, you may get a phone call on the Saturday after your "last day", telling you not to come to work the following Monday, even though you have never missed a day that was not previously scheduled.

review_title: Had a mixed experience with Adecco, and I was one of the Lucky ones
job_title: Document Review Attorney in Mountain View, CA
pros: Temp agency for Google in Mountain View, so useful if you'd like to try and get placed there.
cons: Benefits are bad: No sick days, very minimal health insurance option that was due to be eliminated. Also, it's nearly impossible to qualify for "Holiday Pay", and if you do qualify, there were always problems with getting it paid out. It was usually a week or two late and was only paid when people would email them to complain.

pros: Decent benefits. Most coworkers are willing to help out, especially with basic questions.
cons:
Work/Life balance does not exist. As a recruiter you are on call 24/7.  If you're sick, you must check in multiple times during the day to make sure you're not needed. If you're on vacation, don't forget to check your e-mails. Everything is an emergency according to management.  

An even bigger problem is the lack of training given to the recruiters. A 3 day training class almost a year into your job does not cut it. There are multiple systems to navigate and multiple sets of rules to follow. If you don't know what questions to ask you end up in violation of all kids of policies. It leaves everyone frustrated.

The technology is also VERY behind. The computer systems are antiquated, and while upgrades are coming the roll-outs that have already happened have been disasters.

pros: Overall, Adecco is a great company that creates many opportunities for talented people to succeed and advance their career. Because its global, I know many people who have been able to travel and relocate to other countries for new opportunities. Very talented management, with only a few exceptions. While there are things that can always be improved, I would recommend Adecco to any of my friends or associates.
cons: Because of its size, it takes too long to get things done sometimes. We should be further along than we are in finding innovative ways to deliver value to our clients and candidates. We are making good progress, but we need to move faster.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I felt the recruiters really got to know me, appreciated my skills and work ethic, and worked hard to develop opportunities and to create a good fit between me and the clients.
cons: Temping has its drawbacks.  I've had assignments where the client sort of strung me along with the tenuous possibility of being hired permanently, but in the end companies prefer to keep certain roles as temp roles.  It takes a very disciplined person to continue searching for a permanent job while working full time at a temp job.

pros: One of the only reasons was the same level colleagues I got to work with each day in the corporate office.  Although motivation and leadership was non-existent, the relationships created with my fellow colleagues were strong and kept me motivated during me tenure.
cons: The management side of the organization is mediocre at best.  Organizational wide goals are not communicated effectively or efficiently, leading to chaos and confusion.  The wrong behavioral traits and attitudes are rewarded, resulting in resentment, disrespect, and mistrust in the lower levels of the organization.  Corporate headquarters is segregated into the back-office functions in one location and all senior-level management and above in another downtown location.  I've never seen such ignorance in the message that sends to all lower level employees - that their time and commutes are LESS IMPORTANT than executive level management.  Adecco is now in the midst of declining sales, layoffs, and a bleak outlook from Wall Street and its own investors.

review_title: Steady work with a good boss
pros: I was able to find a contract position that did not have a 1000 hour limit, and I reported to a great recruiter.  I realize this is rare; with this assignment, my work life was great.  35-40 hours/ week and flexible.
cons: At the end of the day, it's a contract position.  You may have ideas or insight that could really help the company, but your ideas aren't given time or aren't valued.  Great work for those who want to do their work and go home; not great work for someone who wants to learn and make a difference.  Or you may have the talent of an employee (vs you being a contractor) who is making much more than you.  Also, you are at the mercy of budget cuts and can be easily let go.

review_title: A lot of room for improvement
job_title: Fixed Management Clerk in Canandaigua, NY
pros: Reasonable rates for geographical location
cons: So many. No job description so you go in blind. They don’t check / don’t care when it comes to checking company culture fit for either the company or the person being brought on board. The company I worked with had a very negative unhappy culture. The misery was intense. And rightly so since they would try to be shifty about paying for less time than the full hours worked. They offered no resolution. Didn’t attempt to resolve disputes.

job_title: Web and Middleware .NET Operations Specialist in Sofia, Sofia (city)
pros: Adecco is an outsourcing company, responsible for providing the working "resource", as they call it, for other big companies in the region. Good discounts for various procedures and stores. Management and HR teams are very well organized and alway comply with the specific company's policy. Have senority bonus for long term employees and pay checks arrive always on time.
cons: No medical insurance, no parking space for Adecco employees, pay grade is always lower than your non-Adecco colleagues. To much bindings on the contract and pay raise is not an option, only specific bonuses. In general it sucks to work as an Adecco employee for bigger companies, with better privileges.

pros: Adecco offers a great on boarding training program and (depending on the area) also provides continued training throughout your employment. There is some room for growth, depending on the type of recruitment you are interested in doing. Light Industrial is their bread and butter so you will have a lot of opportunities if that is the line of work you are in.
cons: Upper management usually is in it for themselves; they generally don't go out of their way to help you rise through the ranks. Also, the work is incredibly demanding... be prepared to work a minimum of 12 hours a day for your first few years if you want to get promoted. The work/life balance is minimal. They require a lot of you and you aren't paid what you should be. In fact, they pay at least $10k less than what the salary guides they give to clients states.

pros:
Great pay" , good working location. A long lunch 
I enjoyed the limited interactions I was discouraged to develop with the providers
cons:
I am a clinical medical assistant and was only permitted to answer phones, make appointments and verify insurance . I am trained and experienced in direct patient care I did not have a positive experience- I did nit received adequate training to properly use telephone headset ,concurrently developed clogged Eustachian tube- and subsequently got Vertigo. As I was temping in a healthcare temping, a PA recommended I go home and seek care. Upon seeing a Dr, returned to work with a note.  Three days later my agent, very pointedly by phone asked me "what's going on with you" and then was instructed to leav my job site.  To date , I have not been re-assigned work , nor had my request to work with another agent been responded to. 
They are not helping people develop and improve the work force 
.

review_title: Horrible Communication, No Attention to Detail
pros: They placed me with an amazing company.
cons: I have been working for Adecco for almost 3 years now.  I would have left 3 years ago if they did not place me with an amazing company.  That is the only good thing that has ever come from them.  From paying me incorrectly, to missing paychecks (up to 6 weeks without a paycheck once) to putting my social down wrong and messing up my taxes they have managed to completely botch everything they touch.  They never return calls, and when I manage to get in touch it's always some young inexperienced recruiter who has no idea what they're doing.  The turnover is terrible.  They refuse to take any responsibility for messing up my taxes last year and I had to threaten legal action to even receive my W2's.  This company is a joke.

review_title: Good learning Experience and then move on!
pros: Good learning experience. Good as the first job for College graduates but then move on..good Corporate Atmosphere,  good benefits package, work life balance.
cons: Favoritism is a big factor here. Management Team has to like to you to promote you or give you a raise. Otherwise, you will be stuck in the same position for years. Micro management, low salaries, NO ROOM FOR ADVANCEMENT.

job_title: Direct Hire Recruiter in Greensburg, PA
pros:
As a current employee of Adecco with almost 10 years of tenure here, I'm consistently impressed with the amount of freedom the company allows of it's employees to brand not only themselves, but the company as a whole.  Adecco truly believes that their employees are the best way to market the company and in turn will invest significantly in training and career advancement.  
   Another huge bonus is the open-door policy from the N. America president, Joyce Russel, all the way to the local branches.  Your voice will not go unheard and creative ideas are always encouraged.  
   I can highly recommend Adecco to anyone looking for a career internally or to explore our opportunities with our clients.
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: QA, Mechanical Assembler, MecWash, Shipping, Stocking in Loveland, CO
pros:
Steady work for the most part.
Easy work.
Inside.
Renovating.
Free coffee DIO.
Some older generations are a 'hoot' to shoot the spit with.
cons:
Very little communication.
Rude employees that feel entitled.
Coworkers try to take the roll of your superior.
Grumpy environment.
Company eliminating work due to lack of quality.
Temps get moved around a lot with little chance of being hired.
Once a temp, always a temp mentality.
They will try to get more out of you for their benefit than you will ever get in return.
I worked hard and had a great attitude, thank goodness I left with that in tact. People are constantly in fear of you taking their job or looking better than them, take my advice, don't play into it just stay positive and look for another job whilst you maintain your job money and life moving forward. They are staying still, you don't have to.

review_title: Eh - could be better, could be worse
job_title: Gift Shop Clerk At A KY State Park in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: I was always paid on time as an Adecco temp, and my contact there called me a couple of times with the offer of extra assignments outside of my normal job's hours. She did not pressure me either way.
cons: It's more of a con for Adecco's client, but the state of Kentucky is increasingly going to try to outsource state park jobs to low-paid temps like I was. Next time you go to a state park, realize that many of the people who will be helping you are not making much more than minimum wage.

pros: They seemed to have plenty of jobs for people. If you are willing to work, they seemed liked they would keep it coming.
cons: I felt like a number, which, I expect at a temporary agency. No surprise there. The staff often did not seem to know what was happening around them.
